fields.title: How old are you?
fields.content: The older you are, the higher your risk for type 2 diabetes.

options.content: As you get older, your risk for type 2 diabetes increases. You can’t stop the aging process, but you can take steps to reduce your risk through lifestyle changes and/or medication at any age.
options.label: Younger than 40

options.content: As you get older, your risk for type 2 diabetes increases. You can’t stop the aging process, but you can take steps to reduce your risk through lifestyle changes and/or medication at any age.
options.label: 40-49 Years

options.content: As you get older, your risk for type 2 diabetes increases. You can’t stop the aging process, but you can take steps to reduce your risk through lifestyle changes and/or medication at any age.
options.label: 50-59 Years

options.content: As you get older, your risk for type 2 diabetes increases. You can’t stop the aging process, but you can take steps to reduce your risk through lifestyle changes and/or medication at any age.
options.label: 60+ Years

fields.title: Do you have a mother, father, sister, or brother with diabetes?
fields.content: A family history of diabetes could contribute to your risk for type 2 diabetes.

options.answer: I have a family history with diabetes.
options.content: There is a link between type 2 diabetes and family history. The risk of type 2 diabetes in people with family history of diabetes is related to environmental and lifestyle factors that family members share as well as to genetics.
options.label: Yes

options.answer: I have no family history with diabetes.
options.content: There is a link between type 2 diabetes and family history. The risk of type 2 diabetes in people with family history of diabetes is related to environmental and lifestyle factors that family members share as well as to genetics.
options.label: No

fields.title: Have you ever been diagnosed with high blood pressure?
fields.content: Having high blood pressure contributes to your overall risk for type 2 diabetes.

options.answer: I have a high blood pressure history.
options.content: High blood pressure not only raises your risk for type 2 diabetes but also increases the risk of heart attack, stroke, eye problems, and kidney disease.
options.label: Yes

options.answer: I have no history of high blood pressure.
options.content: High blood pressure not only raises your risk for type 2 diabetes but also increases the risk of heart attack, stroke, eye problems, and kidney disease.
options.label: No

fields.title: What race or ethnicity best describes you?
fields.content: People from certain racial and ethnic groups are more likely to develop type 2 diabetes than others.

options.label: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

fields.title: Are you physically active?
fields.content: Being inactive can increase your risk for type 2 diabetes.

options.content: Exercising regularly lowers your risk for prediabetes and type 2 diabetes.
options.label: Yes

options.content: Exercising regularly lowers your risk for prediabetes and type 2 diabetes.
options.label: No

fields.title: Are you a man or a woman?
fields.content: Men are more likely than women to have undiagnosed prediabetes; one reason may be that they are less likely to visit their doctors regularly.

options.content: Many women who have gestational diabetes go on to develop type 2 diabetes later in life.
options.label: Woman

womanSub.answer: with a history of gestational diabetes.
womanSub.label: Yes

womanSub.answer: with no history of gestational diabetes.
womanSub.label: No

fields.title: Tell us more about yourself
fields.content: The combination of your weight and height lets us know your Body Mass Index or BMI. People with higher BMIs are at a higher risk.
